articles.headline: Seeking Divine Intervention, or at Least Some Lucky Shorts
articles.snippet: Whether by wearing the same shorts during a winning streak or trusting in a talisman, fervent soccer fans in Brazil often believe match results are in their control.
articles.abstract: Whether by wearing the same shorts during a winning streak or trusting in a talisman, fervent soccer fans in Brazil often believe match results are in their control.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — There is a saying in this coastal city of mixed religious heritages and creeds that goes more or less like this: If superstition decided soccer matches, all matches would end in a tie.

articles.headline: Investors Who Bought Foreclosed Homes in Bulk Look to Sell
articles.snippet: Rising home prices and a declining supply of inexpensive foreclosed houses have led some investment companies to lock in profits by unloading homes.
articles.abstract: Rising home prices and a declining supply of inexpensive foreclosed houses have led some investment companies to lock in profits by unloading homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, buying foreclosed homes to rent out was the sure-thing trade for investment firms backed by money from private equity companies, hedge funds and pension systems. But with the supply of cheap foreclosed homes dwindling, some early investors are looking to cash out a bit by flipping homes to competitors.

articles.headline: Coach Boldly Moves U.S. Forward
articles.snippet: The decisions Coach Jurgen Klinsmann has made, and the way he has executed them, are a back story to the United States’ captivating run at the World Cup.
articles.abstract: The decisions Coach Jurgen Klinsmann has made, and the way he has executed them, are a back story to the United States’ captivating run at the World Cup.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In late March, just before Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national men’s soccer team, went into the meeting in which he demoted Martin Vasquez, his longtime assistant, he asked a staff member with U.S. Soccer to knock on the door and interrupt after about five minutes.

articles.headline: Making Everything Shipshape
articles.snippet: Tacoma, Wash., Seattle and other West Coast ports are spending billions on upgrades to keep themselves competitive in the overall fight for foreign trade.
articles.abstract: Tacoma, Wash., Seattle and other West Coast ports are spending billions on upgrades to keep themselves competitive in the overall fight for foreign trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: TACOMA, Wash. — As construction crews 5,000 miles away are working to widen the Panama Canal to allow much larger ships to sail straight to the East Coast, this historic port city and others along the West Coast are doing everything they can to avoid becoming superfluous.

articles.headline: Airlines’ Rivalry Amplifies Fight Over Bank Guarantees
articles.snippet: Delta, watching Persian Gulf carriers make inroads into Europe, is concerned that loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank in Washington will help them do the same in the United States.
articles.abstract: Delta, watching Persian Gulf carriers make inroads into Europe, is concerned that loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank in Washington will help them do the same in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rise of Persian Gulf airlines has been a boon to Boeing as they snap up its large jets, sometimes with the help of loan guarantees from Washington.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Reporter’s Case Poses Dilemma for Justice Dept.
articles.snippet: The administration confronts a hard choice: demand the testimony of a reporter and risk sending him to jail, or back off from its aggressive pursuit of leaks.
articles.abstract: The administration confronts a hard choice: demand the testimony of a reporter and risk sending him to jail, or back off from its aggressive pursuit of leaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 31, 2005, the C.I.A.’s acting general counsel, John A. Rizzo, received an urgent phone call from the White House about a chapter in James Risen’s coming book, “State of War,” detailing a botched C.I.A. operation in Iran.

articles.headline: Taliban Mount Major Assault in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The group has attacked police outposts and government facilities in several districts of northern Helmand Province, sending the police and military officials scrambling to shore up defenses.
articles.abstract: The group has attacked police outposts and government facilities in several districts of northern Helmand Province, sending the police and military officials scrambling to shore up defenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In one of the most significant coordinated assaults on the government in years, the Taliban have attacked police outposts and government facilities across several districts in northern Helmand Province, sending police and military officials scrambling to shore up defenses and heralding a troubling new chapter as coalition forces prepare to depart.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Taimoor Shah

articles.headline: Here Comes the Judge, in Cuffs
articles.snippet: Three judges in Broward County, Fla., have been arrested recently on D.U.I. charges, leading lawyers to wonder: strange coincidence or sign of a larger problem?
articles.abstract: Three judges in Broward County, Fla., have been arrested recently on D.U.I. charges, leading lawyers to wonder: strange coincidence or sign of a larger problem?
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Lawyers gawked from office windows last month when a BMW S.U.V. swiped a parked police cruiser in the parking lot of a courthouse in Fort Lauderdale, then slammed into a gate over and over again.

articles.headline: When a Health Plan Knows How You Shop
articles.snippet: Household data holds promise in making medical care more efficient, but some fear that it may lead to unequal treatment.
articles.abstract: Household data holds promise in making medical care more efficient, but some fear that it may lead to unequal treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: There may be a link between your Internet use and how often you end up in the emergency room.

articles.headline: The C.E.O. Is My Friend. So Back Off.
articles.snippet: A study’s surprising finding: If company directors have disclosed that they’re friends with the chief executive, they’re even more likely to try to give him a bonus.
articles.abstract: A study’s surprising finding: If company directors have disclosed that they’re friends with the chief executive, they’re even more likely to try to give him a bonus.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was probably a coincidence, but then again maybe not.

articles.headline: James Gorman of Morgan Stanley, Going Against Type
articles.snippet: Forgoing Wall Street flash, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive is finding safer ways for the firm to make money.
articles.abstract: Forgoing Wall Street flash, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive is finding safer ways for the firm to make money.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a stickup, Wall Street style.

articles.headline: The Dazzle and the Desolation of Stadiums in World Cup Host Cities
articles.snippet: Billed as a boon to Brazil, gleaming new stadiums rose for the World Cup — but now residents wonder how they will benefit after the last goal is scored.
articles.abstract: Billed as a boon to Brazil, gleaming new stadiums rose for the World Cup — but now residents wonder how they will benefit after the last goal is scored.
articles.lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — From her crumbling house with the leaky roof, across a new highway from a new World Cup stadium, Maria Ivanilde Oliveira heard everything.

articles.headline: In Military Care, a Pattern of Errors but Not Scrutiny
articles.snippet: An examination of the nation’s military hospitals by The New York Times finds a system where avoidable, sometimes deadly, errors are chronic and scrutiny is sporadic.
articles.abstract: An examination of the nation’s military hospitals by The New York Times finds a system where avoidable, sometimes deadly, errors are chronic and scrutiny is sporadic.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT SILL, Okla. — Jessica Zeppa, five months pregnant, the wife of a soldier, showed up four times at Reynolds Army Community Hospital here in pain, weak, barely able to swallow and fighting a fever. The last time, she declared that she was not leaving until she could get warm.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: A Reignited War Drives Iraqis Out in Huge Numbers
articles.snippet: Iraqis have fled their homes in recent weeks, filled with fear and uncertainty — and a painful sense of familiarity. More than a million Iraqis have been displaced this year, and for many it was not the first time.
articles.abstract: Iraqis have fled their homes in recent weeks, filled with fear and uncertainty — and a painful sense of familiarity. More than a million Iraqis have been displaced this year, and for many it was not the first time.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARBANDIKHAN, Iraq — As Sunni rebels advanced across Iraq in recent weeks, hundreds of thousands of Iraqis were driven from their homes. For many, it was not the first time.

articles.headline: World Cup 2014: Brazil Survives Shootout Against Chile
articles.snippet: After Brazil goalkeeper Júlio César had made two shootout saves, Gonzalo Jara hit the right post, and the ball bounced back across the mouth of the goal and safely away.
articles.abstract: After Brazil goalkeeper Júlio César had made two shootout saves, Gonzalo Jara hit the right post, and the ball bounced back across the mouth of the goal and safely away.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — With the pressure of an anxious nation bearing down on them with each passing minute, the Brazilian players teetered on the brink of a defeat that would have wounded a country’s soul.

articles.headline: In Home Loans, Subprime Fades as a Dirty Word
articles.snippet: Facing a tight credit market, homebuyers are turning to a safer version of the subprime mortgage, a culprit of the 2008 housing crash.
articles.abstract: Facing a tight credit market, homebuyers are turning to a safer version of the subprime mortgage, a culprit of the 2008 housing crash.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALABASAS, Calif. — Martin and Cindy Arroyo knew they were not ideal candidates for a home loan.

articles.headline: Past Road’s End, Democrats Dig for Native Votes
articles.snippet: Democrats consider remote tribal villages so vital to their majority in the Senate that they are building an outreach operation across rural Alaska and on reservations in other states.
articles.abstract: Democrats consider remote tribal villages so vital to their majority in the Senate that they are building an outreach operation across rural Alaska and on reservations in other states.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPASKIAK, Alaska — No roads go this deep into the tundra, especially not for Democrats.

articles.headline: Cup Overflows: You Won’t See Joy Like This in the End Zone
articles.snippet: Unlike the relatively restrained players in American sports leagues, goal scorers at the World Cup unleash celebrations ranging from joyous to defiant to bizarre.
articles.abstract: Unlike the relatively restrained players in American sports leagues, goal scorers at the World Cup unleash celebrations ranging from joyous to defiant to bizarre.
articles.lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — After Pablo Armero of Colombia scored against Greece, he and his teammates broke into a raucous dance routine that evoked the “Shout” scene from the film “Animal House.”

articles.headline: After Supreme Court Ruling, Aereo’s Rivals in TV Streaming Seize Opening
articles.snippet: A victory for traditional American broadcasters in a copyright case does little to protect them from an Internet-powered onslaught.
articles.abstract: A victory for traditional American broadcasters in a copyright case does little to protect them from an Internet-powered onslaught.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Ely saw an opportunity, and he took it.

articles.headline: For Email Newsletters, a Death Greatly Exaggerated
articles.snippet: Email newsletters, old-school artifacts that were supposed to die with dial-up connections, are not only still around, but very much on the march.
articles.abstract: Email newsletters, old-school artifacts that were supposed to die with dial-up connections, are not only still around, but very much on the march.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here at the Media Equation, we pride ourselves on keeping our readers abreast of the newest technologies and approaches in reaching audiences. So it gives us great pleasure to reveal a radical publishing technology that is catching on in news media companies big and small. Ladies and gentlemen, behold: email.

articles.headline: Facebook Tinkers With Users’ Emotions in News Feed Experiment, Stirring Outcry
articles.snippet: Last week Facebook revealed that it had manipulated the news feeds of over half a million randomly selected users to change the number of positive and negative posts they saw.
articles.abstract: Last week Facebook revealed that it had manipulated the news feeds of over half a million randomly selected users to change the number of positive and negative posts they saw.
articles.lead_paragraph: To Facebook, we are all lab rats.

articles.headline: New N.S.A. Chief Calls Damage From Snowden Leaks Manageable
articles.snippet: The director of the National Security Agency, Adm. Michael S. Rogers, described the steps the agency is taking to ensure that no one else can download the information taken by Edward J. Snowden, a former defense contractor.
articles.abstract: The director of the National Security Agency, Adm. Michael S. Rogers, described the steps the agency is taking to ensure that no one else can download the information taken by Edward J. Snowden, a former defense contractor.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The newly installed director of the National Security Agency says that while he has seen some terrorist groups alter their communications to avoid surveillance techniques revealed by Edward J. Snowden, the damage done over all by a year of revelations does not lead him to the conclusion that “the sky is falling.”

articles.headline: G.M. to Set Payouts in Crashes Caused by Flawed Switches
articles.snippet: Kenneth R. Feinberg, a compensation expert who handled the 9/11 settlements, is to announce the plan for General Motors payouts on Monday.
articles.abstract: Kenneth R. Feinberg, a compensation expert who handled the 9/11 settlements, is to announce the plan for General Motors payouts on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A prominent compensation expert hired by General Motors is scheduled to announce a plan here on Monday to distribute money to victims of accidents caused by the automaker’s defective ignition switch.

articles.headline: Flawed Saudi Response Is Cited in Outbreak of the Middle East Virus MERS
articles.snippet: Cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome have more than tripled since the end of 2013, leading health experts to cite grave flaws in the way Saudi health officials have handled the crisis.
articles.abstract: Cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome have more than tripled since the end of 2013, leading health experts to cite grave flaws in the way Saudi health officials have handled the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — As the virus tore through the city’s largest hospital, jumping from bed to bed and afflicting scores of people, terror filled the wards.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Donald G. McNeil Jr

articles.headline: For Goalkeepers in Brazil, Catching Grief Is Part of the Job
articles.snippet: Long ridiculed with terms such as “chicken man” and “lettuce hands,” Brazilian goalkeepers received a huge boost when Júlio César helped propel his team past Chile and into the World Cup quarterfinals.
articles.abstract: Long ridiculed with terms such as “chicken man” and “lettuce hands,” Brazilian goalkeepers received a huge boost when Júlio César helped propel his team past Chile and into the World Cup quarterfinals.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — For years, it has gone without saying in Brazil that fathers do not let their children grow up to be goalkeepers.

articles.headline: Before Shooting in Iraq, a Warning on Blackwater
articles.snippet: Not long after the security firm’s top manager in Iraq told a State Department investigator “that he could kill” him, an inquiry was abandoned. Weeks later, the firm’s guards killed 17 civilians in Iraq.
articles.abstract: Not long after the security firm’s top manager in Iraq told a State Department investigator “that he could kill” him, an inquiry was abandoned. Weeks later, the firm’s guards killed 17 civilians in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just weeks before Blackwater guards fatally shot 17 civilians at Baghdad’s Nisour Square in 2007, the State Department began investigating the security contractor’s operations in Iraq. But the inquiry was abandoned after Blackwater’s top manager there issued a threat: “that he could kill” the government’s chief investigator and “no one could or would do anything about it as we were in Iraq,” according to department reports.

articles.headline: Modern Tools for Mom-and-Pops
articles.snippet: While start-ups like Uber are frequently seen as the enemy of traditional independent merchants, some new tech companies see big opportunity in serving local stores.
articles.abstract: While start-ups like Uber are frequently seen as the enemy of traditional independent merchants, some new tech companies see big opportunity in serving local stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y. — Operators at KES Dispatch keep track of the company’s taxis on a yellow legal pad. They communicate with cars using a two-way radio. Drivers navigate their journeys largely by memory.

articles.headline: After West Bank Kidnapping, 2 Mothers Embody a Divide
articles.snippet: Israel’s security crackdown has raised questions about the asymmetry of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the value of lives on both sides.
articles.abstract: Israel’s security crackdown has raised questions about the asymmetry of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the value of lives on both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOF AYALON, Israel — It was about 4 a.m. on a Friday when the police banged on Rachel Fraenkel’s door in this Jerusalem suburb looking for her 16-year-old son, Naftali, and a friend he studies with at a yeshiva in the West Bank. The night before, Naftali had texted his parents saying he was going to hitchhike back home. They had no idea he had never arrived.

articles.headline: Boom Meets Bust in Texas: Atop Sea of Oil, Poverty Digs In
articles.snippet: A boom has helped produce fortunes for some in Texas, but poverty endures in shantytowns without basic services like water and sewers.
articles.abstract: A boom has helped produce fortunes for some in Texas, but poverty endures in shantytowns without basic services like water and sewers.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARDENDALE, Tex. — From the window of her tin-roofed trailer, Judy Vargas can glimpse a miraculous world. It is as close as the dust kicked up by the trucks barreling by but seems as distant as Mars.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Supreme Court Rejects Contraceptives Mandate for Some Corporations
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 that family-owned corporations cannot be required under the Affordable Care Act to pay for insurance coverage for contraception.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 that family-owned corporations cannot be required under the Affordable Care Act to pay for insurance coverage for contraception.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that requiring family-owned corporations to pay for insurance coverage for contraception under the Affordable Care Act violated a federal law protecting religious freedom. It was, a dissent said, “a decision of startling breadth.”

articles.headline: As Recalls Expand, G.M. Offers Plan for Victims of Faulty Ignition Switch
articles.snippet: After years of delay, the automaker is moving rapidly to try to handle death and injury claims from accidents caused by a faulty ignition switch.
articles.abstract: After years of delay, the automaker is moving rapidly to try to handle death and injury claims from accidents caused by a faulty ignition switch.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — General Motors on Monday became consumed once again by the safety crisis it cannot seem to shake, announcing the recall of 8.4 million more vehicles worldwide — most of them for an ignition defect similar to the flaw that the company failed to disclose in other models for more than a decade.
